Being rich and famous is not sinful. However, making that a primary pursuit in lifeÂ isÂ sinful. â€œPeople who long to be rich fall into temptation and are trapped by many foolish and harmful desires that plunge them into ruin and destructionâ€ (1 Timothy 6:9, NLT). â€œDo not toil to acquire wealthâ€ (Proverbs 23:4, ESV).

1. First and foremost is Jesus. WhenÂ tempted by Satan, He intentionally rejected the opportunities to become rich and famous (Matthew 4:1â€“11). 2.Â JosephÂ was sold into slavery by his brothers. As a slave, he had no ambitions to be rich and famous. He only did the work that was put before him. In Potipharâ€™s house, Josephâ€™s faithfulness resulted in his being put in charge of everything. Later, in jail, he helped his fellow prisoners, earning a trust that ultimately led to his being put in charge of all of Egypt, second only to Pharaoh. In short, Joseph focused on what God wanted him doing, and as a result he became one of the most powerful and famous men in the world (seeÂ Genesis 37â€”41).

3. He was not wealthy, but theÂ apostle PaulÂ was perhaps the most famous Christian ever to live. How did his fame become worldwide and timeless? He simply did what God put him on earth to do: make disciples. He certainly had a claim to worldly fame, describing some of his accomplishments inÂ Philippians 3:4â€“6. Yet what did he think about these pursuits that would have warranted fame? â€œWhatever were gains to me I now consider loss for the sake of Christâ€ (verse 7). Paulâ€™s ambition was never to become famous or gather the accolades of men. His burning ambition was to do Godâ€™s work and glorify Christ. That was his higher calling.

InÂ Matthew 6:10â€“20, Jesus teaches us not store up treasures on earth, but in heaven. Then He says, â€œYou cannot serve both God and moneyâ€ (verse 24). And â€œSeek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things [the basic necessities of life] will be given to you as wellâ€ (verse 33). That is, stop trying to be rich and famous, and instead simply seek after God, living out His purposes for your life. If God wants earthly riches to come your way, they will.

For those whose ambition is to be rich, the Bible has many cautions. Jesus said that it is difficult for the rich to enter the kingdom of heaven (Matthew 19:24). Material wealth has a way of taking our eyes off of whatâ€™s important and eternal. Jesusâ€™Â parable of the rich foolÂ inÂ Luke 12:16â€“21Â teaches that it is foolish to store up earthly things and take no thought of heavenly things.

As for pursuing fame, the Bible is equally cautioning: â€œThose who exalt themselves will be humbledâ€ (Matthew 23:12). Paul says that â€œa person with a changed heart seeks praise from God, not from peopleâ€ (Romans 2:29, NLT). James asks, â€œDonâ€™t you know that friendship with the world means enmity against God? Therefore, anyone who chooses to be a friend of the world becomes an enemy of Godâ€ (James 4:4).

Those who are rich and famous often struggle to obey basic biblical commands such as â€œBe content with what you haveâ€ (Hebrews 13:5) and â€œDo not be proud, but enjoy the company of the lowly. Do not be conceitedâ€ (Romans 12:16, BSB) and â€œNow listen, you rich people, weep and wail because of the misery that is coming on youâ€ (James 5:1).

To be clear, itâ€™s not wrong to have wealth. Itâ€™s theÂ loveÂ of moneyÂ that is a root of all kinds of evil (1 Timothy 6:10). But those with wealth should understand where the wealth comes from (God), the purpose for having it (to further Godâ€™s work), and itâ€™s transitory nature (seeÂ Proverbs 23:5).

Ecclesiastes 2:24Â notes, â€œA person can do nothing better than to eat and drink and find satisfaction in their own toil.â€ But the same passage clarifies the Source of our blessings: â€œThis too, I see, is from the hand of God, for without him, who can eat or find enjoyment?â€ (verses 24â€“25).
